The Palestinian people have been waiting 64 years for the realisation of their legitimate and inalienable right to independent statehood. This principle has been reaffirmed in several UN resolutions over the years. The request made to the UN General Assembly by the President of the Palestinian National Authority for the recognition of the State of Palestine, sovereign and viable, with its pre-1967 borders, including East Jerusalem, as a full member of the UN, is the logical conclusion of all those resolutions and principles in the UN Charter. However, the reality in the territory is the consolidation and advancement of Israeli occupation, supported by successive US administrations, with the connivance of the EU. In doing so, it submits the Palestinian people to various forms of violence and oppression. At a time when justice, clarity and unconditional support for the inalienable right of the Palestinian people are being called for, this resolution is ambiguous, as it shields the continued imposition of constraints that favour the continuance of the situation that has existed here for decades. We therefore did not vote in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Ilda Figueiredo (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) Human rights are indeed indivisible, but what is happening is that the European Union is not fulfilling this precept, as while it is taking positive steps in terms of rights based on gender and sexual orientation, it is involved in an accelerated process of denying and even destroying social rights – which are human rights – as well as economic and political rights. These attacks affect everyone, including the social groups given the greatest mention in this resolution.

At the same time, several EU countries and the EU itself are involved in operations of intervention and aggression, as in the case of Libya, or of condoning crimes, as in the case of Israeli crimes against the Palestinian people, or, in the past, involvement in acts of profound disrespect for human rights, such as the US Central Intelligence Agency’s flights and secret prisons, which undermine the principles set out in this resolution. In other words, the EU lacks credibility when it talks about ‘universal and indivisible’ human rights.

Although we voted for this motion for a resolution, we therefore reject the idea, in the name of human rights, that there should be any tactics of intervention or even aggression now or in the future, as these themselves are gross violations of human rights and international law itself.

 
  
 		 

  Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D), in writing. – (SK) Respecting, transposing and upholding the universal nature of human rights is part of the ethical and legal acquis of the European Union and one of the cornerstones of European unity and integration. Despite that, in the European Union and third countries there are daily instances of human rights violations based on sexual orientation and gender identity. The EU and its Member States should guarantee human rights in their own policies and procedures in order to strengthen the EU’s position and its credibility in the UNCHR. The EU attaches a great deal of importance to universal and inviolable human rights and has included the issues of sexual orientation and gender identity as part of its activities in the UN, in regional bodies and in some of its bilateral dialogues on human rights. Despite this, a number of the contracting bodies of the UN monitoring human rights, special rapporteurs and agencies, as well as the general secretary of the UN and the UN High Commissioner for human rights have expressed major concern at the human rights violations that lesbians, gays, bisexuals and transsexuals all over the world encounter. I therefore believe that this situation should be dealt with holistically and that the Commission draw up a comprehensive plan for combating homophobia, transphobia and discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity.

 
  
 		 

  Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D), in writing. − Article 1 of the UN Universal Declaration on Human Rights reads ‘All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights. They are endowed with reason and conscience and should act towards one another in a spirit of brotherhood’. On 17 June 2011, the UN Human Rights Council reaffirmed the universality of this Declaration by adopting a first resolution on ‘Human rights, sexual orientation and gender identity’. This resolution is a significant step for safeguarding the rights of the LGBT community, for it acknowledges human rights violations based on sexual orientation and gender identity; it calls for better protection of the rights of this community, and it recognises the legitimacy of human rights defenders working on these issues. While I welcome this positive development in the UN, I remain alert to the ongoing human rights violations, based on sexual orientation and gender identity, which still take place in many countries around the world. The fact that 21 EU members co-sponsored this resolution sends a powerful message to our citizens, our colleagues and partners overseas. It demonstrates the EU’s commitment to human rights, freedom of expression and freedom of choice. These rights, ultimately, are the core values of the EU.

 
  
 		 

  Sylvie Guillaume (S&D), in writing. – (FR) The vote on this motion for a resolution is particularly important for the defence of the rights of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people who are still too often subject to discrimination, and even violence, within the European Union. In that regard, we should welcome the work of the United Nations which seeks to promote the rights of transgender people and the recognition of gender identity.

Contrary to what several members of the Union pour un Mouvement Populaire party would have us believe in France, following their recent call for the French Government to withdraw school textbooks explaining the impact of socio-cultural context on gender identity, we should stress the fact that gender identity is not merely a biological given.

Finally, we should also urge that gender and sexual orientation should be fully taken into account in the processing of asylum applications, so that the vulnerability of these individuals can be identified at the earliest possible opportunity and the appropriate procedures followed.

 
  
 		 

  Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE), in writing. − This resolution highlights the fact that discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity is still a reality both within and outwith the EU. The resolution calls on the EU’s institutions and Member States to take action to bring about a change in attitudes and I entirely endorse its sentiments.

 
  
 		 

  Vladimír Maňka (S&D), in writing. − (SK) I must categorically express my concern at the many cases of human rights violations and the spread of discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity in the European Union as well as in third countries. The EU aims to ensure that international standards on human rights are fully upheld regardless of the sexual orientation or gender identity of the individual. The EU Member States have long supported the inclusion of sexual orientation and gender identity among the Human Rights Council’s activities on human rights and in other bodies of the UN. The rights of lesbians, gays, bisexuals and transsexuals, including the right to bodily integrity, the right to privacy and family life, the right to freedom of opinion and expression, the right of free assembly, the right to non-discrimination, the right of free movement and the right to asylum are not yet always fully observed in the European Union. The Member States and the Commission must put all their efforts into tackling this inequality. The Commission should draft a comprehensive plan to tackle homophobia, transphobia and discrimination based on sexual discrimination and gender identity.

 
  
 		 

  David Martin (S&D), in writing. − I voted for this report which calls on the High Representative and Member States to systematically promote, in partnership with third countries, the protection and respect of human rights in relation to sexual orientation and gender identity at the United Nations and in other multilateral fora, and bilaterally in their human rights dialogues.

 
  
 		 

  Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (FR) The European Union is so quick to lecture on human rights, but it needs to start by respecting the universal principle of equal rights. This joint resolution has the merit of recalling that fact, and of calling for respect in relation to lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people. Nothing should be able to challenge the right of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people to decent work on equal terms with all other workers. Nothing should be able to challenge people’s equality in all civil unions and their ensuing rights, or their right to medical treatment and social security. To do so would mean denying equality between citizens, which is the very foundation of democracy.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Melo (PPE), in writing. − (PT) The right to freedom and the principle of equality are fundamental EU values. This is why any kind of discrimination is completely rejected by all of the Member States, especially discrimination based on sexual orientation. Unfortunately, however, we are aware that there are still many states that are still not governed by these principles, so that many men and women still suffer discrimination all over the world, based on their different sexual orientation. We must keep working to prevent such discrimination from continuing.

 
  
 		 

  Willy Meyer (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (ES) Unfortunately, there are still many violations of human rights and general discrimination on the grounds of sexual orientation and gender identity, both in the European Union and third countries. This resolution condemns that fact, and calls on the Member States and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Ms Ashton, to put into place all the necessary mechanisms to bring this situation to a permanent end. That is why I voted in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Alexander Mirsky (S&D), in writing. − In June 2011, the UN Human Rights Council (UNHRC) adopted the first-ever UN resolution on ‘Human rights, sexual orientation and gender identity’. MEPs in several groups have expressed the wish to echo this historical development by: voicing the European Parliament’s endorsement of this resolution and its welcoming positive developments in the field of sexual orientation and gender identity at the UN in recent years; encouraging the HR/VP and Member States to push for LGBT rights at the UN and bilaterally; calling on the EU and Member States to better safeguard LGBT people’s fundamental rights in the EU. I abstained.

 
  
 		 

  Claudio Morganti (EFD), in writing. – (IT) I voted against this motion for a resolution, because I believe it is right to protect the rights of all, but obviously there must be limits.

I absolutely cannot accept that among the alleged rights is the right to a family, as is explicitly stated in paragraph 11. The family is one thing, and one thing only, namely that formed between a man and a woman.

I therefore feel that this resolution pushes far beyond the acceptable: certainly, it is not the first time that the European Union has gone in this direction, but we in the Lega will always vehemently reject this wholly insupportable idea. The family should remain as it has been traditionally: a father, a mother and children.

 
  
 		 

  Mariya Nedelcheva (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I voted in favour of the resolution on sexual orientation and gender identity at the United Nations Human Rights Council. There needs to be greater public awareness of human rights violations on the grounds of sexual orientation and gender identity. Even in the 21st century, this type of violation happens on a daily basis. This is the case all over the world, including in Europe. Discrimination is pervasive in our societies, whether in an open or implied manner.

The Commission and the Member States should continue to fight against discrimination both within and outside EU borders. We should keep up with the times. When I see that confusion over gender identity is categorised as a disorder in the International Classification of Diseases (ICD), it is a sad reminder that we continue to close our eyes, perhaps out of hypocrisy, to a social reality that is nevertheless part of the furniture.

 
  
 		 

  Georgios Papanikolaou (PPE), in writing. – (EL) The European Commission and the World Health Organisation have repeatedly received complaints about infringements of human rights and widespread discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, both in the European Union and in third countries. Obviously, action by the UN notwithstanding, there are serious problems and the Members States need to commit to more effective anti-discrimination policies, by adopting legislative acts that guarantee protection for diversity, by cooperating with each other and by exchanging best practices with third countries. However, attention must be paid both to sources of funding to promote such cooperation and to preferred definitions and references, especially on the question of sexual orientation and gender identity. That is why I rejected amendments which do not safeguard these conditions, but voted in favour of the report as a whole.

 
  
 		 

  Maria do Céu Patrão Neves (PPE), in writing. – (PT) I voted in favour of this resolution that requires the Member States to engage constructively, in partnership with third countries, in the Universal Periodic Review and treaty body procedures to ensure that human rights in relation to sexual orientation and gender identity are fully upheld in the European Union and in third countries.

 
  
 		 

  Bernd Posselt (PPE), in writing. − (DE) Because human rights form the foundation of and lie at the heart of the work of the European Parliament and because we strongly oppose any discrimination against people, we are particularly sensitive to these matters being misused for ideological purposes. This is the reason why my colleagues from the Christian Social Union (CSU), many other Christian Democrats and I myself have voted against this motion for a resolution and against most of the amendments submitted by the groups on the left and the Greens. We base our approach on the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, together with the constitutions of the Member States and Christian values. Marriage is and will remain a permanent relationship between a man and a woman, who, together with their children, form a family. The Charter of Fundamental Rights explicitly states that the definition of marriage and the family remains a matter for the Member States. For this reason, subjects such as same-sex partnerships do not belong in a resolution on human rights and neither does treating them as the equivalent of marriage, which is completely unacceptable.

 
  
 		 

  Paulo Rangel (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The defence and safeguarding of human rights are not only integral to the European cultural tradition, but also the starting point for EU law. In view of this, in everything that it does, the European Union ensures the defence of a policy direction founded and centred on the protection of the human being. As this is the scope of this resolution, which has a particular focus on sexual orientation and gender identity, I voted in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Robert Rochefort (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) Human rights are one of the ethical and legal pillars of the European Union. At all times, it has argued and worked in favour of their respect, promotion and protection. Those efforts should continue. However, it is also vital to remember and protect the indivisibility of human rights. They have to apply to everyone, regardless of gender, sexual orientation or gender identity. Efforts in that area are increasing in major international organisations, and the EU was duty-bound to affirm its commitment to the protection of human rights for all. Violations of those rights, through discriminatory practices or acts of violence, should end as soon as possible. The EU should establish an open, respectful dialogue both within its territory and as part of its relations with third countries. I therefore welcome the adoption of this motion for a resolution in the European Parliament plenary sitting.

 
  
 		 

  Zuzana Roithová (PPE) , in writing. - (CS) This motion for a resolution of the European Parliament is very general, accusing Member States of daily human rights violations relating to sexual orientation and gender identity, without stating one example. Neither the UN report nor this resolution are binding documents, but despite this it is a pity that these declaratory texts contain so many errors and superficial judgments, as well as poorly cited documents, certain rights deliberately extracted from the body of human rights and no examples provided of their violation. For these reasons, I did not back the report. There is, moreover, no reason for such a resolution at this moment.

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. − In favour. The European Parliament: 1. reiterates its concern regarding the numerous human rights violations and widespread discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, both in the European Union and in third countries; 2. acknowledges and supports the work already undertaken by the Human Rights Council, the UN Secretary-General, the High Commissioner for Human Rights, UN human rights treaty bodies, special rapporteurs and other UN agencies to ensure that international human rights standards apply fully, regardless of a person’s sexual orientation and gender identity; 3. welcomes the adoption of Resolution A/HRC/17/19 on human rights, sexual orientation and gender identity by the Human Rights Council.

 
  
 		 

  Joanna Senyszyn (S&D), in writing. – (PL) I endorsed the resolution on human rights, sexual orientation and gender identity at the United Nations. I would like to stress the need for the Member States to act on the findings of reports published by the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights, and in particular the findings contained in its report of November 2010 entitled ‘Homophobia, transphobia and discrimination on grounds of sexual orientation and gender identity’. In relation to this, I also call on the European Commission to draw up and introduce an EU instrument to tackle abuse and violence caused by hatred of LGBT people and motivated by prejudice.

I also support the call expressed in the resolution for the active promotion of human rights in relation to sexual orientation and gender identity in partnership with third countries. Bilateral human rights dialogues and use of the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights are important in this respect. It is essential that the issues of sexual orientation and gender identity be a permanent part of the work of the Human Rights Council and of other UN bodies. This subject should be discussed at the 19th session of the Human Rights Council in 2012.

 
  
 		 

  Thomas Ulmer (PPE), in writing. − (DE) I have voted against the report, because it is one of an endless series of well-meaning reports which sound good, but which have very little to do with reality.

 
  
 		 

  Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (FR) On 28 September 2011, the European Parliament adopted by a very large majority (442 votes in favour; 104 against) a resolution on human rights violations based on sexual orientation and gender identity. The issue of the need to fight against discrimination in this area is of universal significance, both in the framework of EU foreign policy and within the Member States.

The resolution reaffirms the fundamental rights of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people, including the right to a family life. Moreover, the resolution text was strengthened in plenary by the adoption of joint amendments from various left-wing political groups, and even amendments tabled by the Confederal Group of the European United Left – Nordic Green Left, which called for the depsychiatrisation of the transsexual and transgender journey, free choice of care providers, simplification of the process of changing identity, and for costs to be met by social security schemes.

I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

 
  
 		 

  Anna Záborská (PPE), in writing. − (SK) It seems to have become the rule that major issues such as the basic values of the EU in the UN are slipped on to the agenda of the parliamentary part-sessions at the last moment. The draft motion for a resolution demanding the unconditional transposition of so-called 'new' human rights, which sexual orientation and gender identity are deemed to be, into all aspects of EU foreign policy has only been available in one language. Only one spokesman from each political group has been able to speak on the matter. This makes it hard to shake off a sense that someone is trying to obstruct legitimate debate on these issues. That is a pity. It also angers me that any expression of doubt as to whether pigeon-holing groups of people in society at large on the basis of their sexual orientation or identity is the right way to go is automatically pilloried as homophobia, transphobia or discrimination. Human rights policy should be inclusive. That is why I voted against the tabled resolution.
